INSTRUCTIONS TO CANDIDATES

•   Write your session number in the boxes above.
•   Do not open this examination paper until instructed to do so.
•   Section A: answer all questions.
•   Section B: answer one question.
•   Write your answers in the boxes provided.

                                                          –2–                       M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

                                                     Section a

Answer all questions. Write your answers in the boxes provided.

1.      Approximately 900 million car trips are made each day in the US, half by people travelling
        alone and for less than five miles.  The Segway® Personal Transporter is a green transport
        system for short-distance single-occupancy journeys.   Figure 1 shows the basic model for
        urban use.  There are several different models, e.g. for commuting to work, as a golf cart and
        for off-road use (see Figure 2).   The Segway® is powered by Lithium-ion batteries which
        take 8–10 hours to charge (equivalent to 0.704 kg CO2).  Once charged the Segway® has an
        average range of 20 km (16–24 km depending on a range of factors).   Figure 3 shows the
        average fuel mix used for electricity production in the US.  Table 1 shows the fuel efficiency of
        different vehicles.  1 gallon of fuel contains 2.421 kg of carbon and oxidises to produce 8.788 kg
        of carbon dioxide emissions.

 Figure 1: The Segway® Personal Transporter                       Figure 2: The off-road model of the Segway®
 for Urban Use                                                    Personal Transporter




                                                                                    [Source: www.segway.com]
                                                                  Figure 3: Average fuel mix for electricity
                                                                  production in the US.
                                                                             Coal
                                                                             49.8 %


                                                                                                            Other Renewables
                                                                                                            2.3 %


                   [Source: www.segway.com]                                                                 Natural Gases
                                                                                                            17.9 %
       Table 1: Fuel efficiency of different vehicles              Nuclear                               Other Gases
                                    Km per Gallon                  19.9 %                                0.4 %
                                                                                      Other
                                                                                                 Petroleum
                                                                                      0.2 %
     Large car                                15                                                 3.0 %
     Small diesel car                         37                                         Hydroelectric
                                                                                         6.5 %
     Motorbike                                50
     Hybrid car                               55                                    [Source: www.segway.com]

                                          Used with the permission of Segway Inc.
                                                                     This question continues on the following page)

(Question 1 continued)

     (a)   (i)    State the major fuel used in electricity production in the US.                                                                        [1]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




           (ii)   State one factor which will determine the actual range of the Segway® Personal
                  Transporter once fully charged.                                                                                                       [1]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




           (iii) Outline one way in which the design of the off-road model of the Segway® Personal
                 Transporter shown in Figure 2 differs from the basic model shown in Figure 1.                                                          [2]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

(Question 1 continued)

     (b)   (i)    Identify why the Segway® Personal Transporter does not produce carbon dioxide
                  emissions during use but is quoted as creating 0.704 kg of CO2 per recharge,
                  i.e. per 20 km.                                                                                                                       [2]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




           (ii)   Calculate the carbon dioxide emissions which would be produced by the small
                  diesel car in travelling 20 km.                                                                                                       [2]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




     (c)   (i)    State one dimension of the Segway® Personal Transporter which is adjustable for
                  different users.                                                                                                                      [1]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




           (ii)   Explain the percentile range that the Segway® Personal Transporter would be
                  designed for.                                                                                                                         [3]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




                                                                                   (This question continues on the following page)
                                                                        –5–                              M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

(Question 1 continued)

                                                                                                    Figure 4: Evaluating protective
     Protective head gear design is a compromise between the                                        head gear on a hemispherical anvil
     level of protection it offers, how heavy it is and how hot
     it makes the wearer.  Users prefer light and well vented
     designs even though they may offer less protection.  
     Designs are evaluated against standards (see Table 2),
     e.g. for the amount of impact they can withstand.  In an
     impact test a helmeted headform is dropped from different
     heights against different shaped anvils (see Figure 4).




                                                                                                     © Head Protection Evaluations. Used with permission


           Table 2: Required impact energies for protective head gear in different standards
                                                               FF
                                                           DIIIF
                                                           D
                                                           D   F FE
                                                                 F ER
                                                                   E RE
                                                                     REEN
                                                                        NT
                                                                        N TSSST
                                                                          T   TA
                                                                              T AN
                                                                                AN DA
                                                                                  ND
                                                                                   D AR
                                                                                     A RD
                                                                                       RDDSSS
                                                         IMPACT ENERGIES, FOR EACH ANVIL SHAPE USED
                               Flat Anvil            Hemispherical Kerbstone             No. of impacts per
                                                                                                          Total Impact
                                                     Anvil               Anvil           helmet           Energy/helmet
              Snell B-84 97.8 joules                 58.7 joules         N/A             4 (2 each anvil) 313 joules
              BS: 6863         52.2  joules          N/A                 52.2 joules     2 (1 each anvil) 104 joules
              Snell B-90       100  joules           65 joules           N/A             4 (2 each anvil) 330 joules
              Snell B-95       110  joules           72 joules           72 joules       4 (1 each anvil + 1)
                                                                                                          Min 326 joules
                                                                                                          Max 364 joules
              EN 1078          S–M–L            N/A                 S–M–L           2 (1 each anvil)      Min 81 joules
                               46 – 69 – 90                         35 – 49 – 64                          Max 154 joules
              Note: European EN helmet standards uses test headforms varying from 3.1kg for the smallest to 6.1kg for
              the largest size. The different weights, and tests, are listed for small, medium and large headforms.


                                              © Head Protection Evaluations. Used with permission

     (d)    (i)    State the type of evaluation shown in Figure 4.                                                                                        [1]

                     . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

           (ii)   Explain why user trials are not used to evaluate the protective head gear.                                                            [3]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

     (e)   (i)    Identify one reason for using test headforms of different weights.                                                                    [2]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




           (ii)   Identify one reason why different anvil shapes are used to test the head gear.                                                        [2]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                                                                             –7–                              M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

2.      James Dyson invented the Ball-barrow in 1974 after becoming dissatisfied with the wheels
        of traditional wheelbarrows (see Figure 5) sinking into soft ground.  The Ball-barrow has a
        ball-shaped wheel which rides over soft ground without sinking and absorbs shock when used
        on rough ground.  It also has feet that don’t sink in mud and a plastic bin that doesn’t rust.

          Figure 5: Traditional wheelbarrow                                                       Figure 6: Dyson’s Ball-barrow




     [http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2008-07-185_Construction_                                   www.dyson.co.uk. Used with permission.
              wheelbarrow_at_duke.jpg. Image by Ildar Sagdejev]



        (a)    Outline one way in which Dyson’s Ball-barrow is an example of constructive discontent.                                                           [2]


                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




        (b)    Identify one way in which Dyson might have worked with users to develop a clearer
               understanding of problems experienced with the traditional wheelbarrow.                                                                          [2]


                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




                                                                                                                                                      Turn over
                                                                         –8–                              M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

3.   Figures 7 and 8 show a spun carbon fibre chair designed by Mathias Bengtsson and produced
     by filament winding.

                                              Figures 7 and 8: Spun Carbon Chair




                                              www.bengtssondesign.com. Used with permission.

     (a)   Describe the process of filament winding.                                                                                                        [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




     (b)   Outline one advantage of producing the chair using filament winding.                                                                             [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                                                                             –9–                              M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

4.      Injection-moulded preforms and caps (see Figure 9) can be purchased in standard sizes for the
        production of bottles for water and soft drinks (see Figure 10).

        Figure 9: Standard preforms and caps                                                       Figure 10: PET water bottles




     Source: www.teachersource.com. Used with the permission of                     Source: www.get-inc.com/BottleMfgBlowMolding.htm. Used with
                         Educational Innovations.                                            the permission of Global Water & Energy Ltd.



        (a)    State the process which would be used for the production of PET water bottles from the
               preforms shown in Figure 9.                                                                                                                      [1]


                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




        (b)    Discuss one advantage of purchasing standard preforms and caps for the production of
               PET water bottles for the manufacturer.                                                                                                          [3]


                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

5.   The Powertraveller company has developed a range of portable battery products for use with
     laptops and other electronic devices, including the Minigorilla (see Figure 11).  Powertraveller
     was the first company to develop this type of product.

                                                      Figure 11: Minigorilla




               Source: www.powertraveller.com/iwantsome/primatepower/minigorilla. Used with permission.



     (a)   Identify the corporate strategy adopted by the Powertraveller company.                                                                           [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




     (b)   Outline one way in which the Minigorilla can be described as a global product.                                                                   [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
                                                                        – 11 –                            M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

6.   (a)   Describe a superalloy.                                                                                                                           [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




     (b)   Outline one reason why nickel-based superalloys are appropriate materials for application
           in aircraft engines.                                                                                                                             [2]


            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

            . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .




                                                                                                                                                  Turn over
                                                                      – 12 –                            M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

                                                                Section b

Answer one question. Write your answers in the boxes provided.

7.   Figure 12 shows the Tandem Sling Chair.  It was originally designed by husband and wife design
     team Charles and Ray Eames for airports in Washington and Chicago.  It is now widely used
     in airports and other public buildings around the world.  The brief was to develop a multiple-
     seating system which facilitated security checks, looked good (aesthetics) and was easy to
     maintain (see Figure 13).  The aluminium frame is produced by high-pressure die casting.

           Figure 12: Tandem Sling Chair                                      Figure 13: The chair is widely used in airports
                                                                                      and other public access areas




        www.hermanmiller.co.uk. Used with permission                                     www.hermanmiller.co.uk. Used with permission

     (a)    (i)    Describe the process of high-pressure die casting.                                                                                    [2]


                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




            (ii)   Outline one advantage of using high-pressure die casting to produce the
                   metal frame.                                                                                                                          [2]


                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                    . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 




                                                                                    (This question continues on the following page)
                                                                     – 13 –                            M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

(Question 7 continued)

     (b)   (i)    Describe what is meant by the term factor of safety.                                                                                  [2]

                                                                    – 15 –                            M11/4/DESTE/HP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

8.   A homeowner is considering installing a photovoltaic power system (see Figure 14).  Sunlight
     falling on the photovoltaic (PV) panel generates electricity which is passed via a charge
     controller to charge a 12-volt battery.  It can be output directly as 12-volt direct current (DC) or
     passed to an inverter and alternating current (AC) produced.

                                    Figure 14: Photovoltaic power system




                                                                                       charge
                                                                                      controller




                                       inverter                                         battery




                                      AC output                                       DC output




     (a)   (i)   Outline one limitation of the use of solar and wind energy as alternatives for
                 fossil fuels.                                                                                                                         [2]


                  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

                  different stages of the product lifecycle to evaluate the Alessi Anna G corkscrew.                                                    [9]


                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
                   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
